results.title: From stone to bronze
results.creator_credit: Robert Raymond, Christopher McCullough and Opus Films
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Out of the fiery furnace”.
Episode 1 in the fascinating series called “Out of the fiery furnace.” Opening in the Stone Age this episode explores how mankind came to recognize metals, showing their accidental production in an Indian pottery kiln, and an experiment in smelting copper in the Sinai using Egyptian techniques of about 1500 BC.

results.title: From sociable six to noisy nine [col]
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Crawley Films and Judith Crawley
results.brief_description: The film looks into the meaning of various forms of conduct in children from six to nine years and suggests ways in which parents may guide them through a challenging, often trying phase of development. In a family with three children we observe how the parents cope with often baffling situations.

results.title: From silence to speech
results.brief_description: Training children to speak in Victorian institutions for the education of the deaf. It is essential that deaf children begin education early, and at the Princess Elizabeth Kindergarten, children are taught to lipread in order to associate lip movements with vocal sounds. As they grow older, children continue to the Victorian School for Deaf Children where they continue speech training, commence primary education, play games, learn handcrafts, carpentry and domestic training.

results.title: From school to work bench
results.brief_description: The training of the future skilled workers of West Germany. At the end of an elementary school education boys and girls are tested by vocational guidance experts; visits to factories, agricultural schools, business and domestic science colleges etc give an insight into the demands and qualifications required for the many skilled crafts and the simplest professions of this modern age.

results.title: From runaway to hippie
results.brief_description: A critical view of the “drop-out” society includes a report on drug abuse among American Juvenile delinquents and their attraction to communities such as the San Francisco Hippies. Designed as a warning to young people against the dangers of drug taking, the film also claims that interest in drugs is stimulated by the mass media.
